comments.body:
Logic update: Check all the file-level (except 1 and 2) without a note for any children that don't have a note--the important thing is that the lowest-level components all have a note

Run on row 3, where row 2 is collection-level (0), G is the level and J is the note

```
=IF(AND(
#node is file level
G3>=3, 
#and has no restriction note
ISBLANK(J3), 
#and is leaf, i.e. following is either the same or a higher level (=smaller number)
G4<=G3), 
#then, if true
#check if note of first parent is blank
IF(ISBLANK(LOOKUP(2,1/($G$2:G2=(G3-1)), $J$2:J3)), 
#then, if true, return true (i.e. this is of concern)
TRUE, 
#else return false (i.e. not of concern)
FALSE), 
#else return false
FALSE)
```

cicognara-rails.title: Reindex to see if missing objects show up

comments.body:
I re-ran the [manual index process](https://github.com/pulibrary/cicognara-rails#manually-reindexing) and while doing it I noticed that the latest Getty files on the server (`resourcedump_2023-03-14-part?.zip`) look partially downloaded. 

Notice in the picture below that file `resourcedump_2023-03-14-part3.zip` is too small and there is no file `resourcedump_2023-03-14-part4.zip` even though one is listed in the [Getty endpoint](https://portal.getty.edu/resources/json_data/resourcedump.xml)

![new_and_old](https://github.com/pulibrary/cicognara-rails/assets/568286/7b76e0e8-f02e-479b-b3ff-3289473852dd)

Below is how the `resourcedump_2023-03-14-part?.zip` files look on the server after I manually re-downloaded them:

![all_new](https://github.com/pulibrary/cicognara-rails/assets/568286/c238aae2-3680-4858-a906-9df052a5224f)

### Tried so far

- With @rladdusaw, creating an app using the [initializr](https://start.spring.io/)
- Creating a new route
    - creating a MVCC test to assert that we get a 200 status response
    - authorizing anonymous users to access it with a `SecurityFilterChain`
    - accepting a parameter through RequestParam
- Use VSCode's very pleasant TDD experience to write tests (JUnit and Mockito), then implement the features.
- Use [Solrj documentation](https://solr.apache.org/guide/8_4/using-solrj.html#querying-in-solrj) to communicate with Solr.
- With @christinach, use checkstyle to lint the code (and attempt to configure it -- we didn't quite figure that out)
- Use semgrep and bearer SAST tools.  Both were green -- not sure if there are problems they should have found ðŸ˜œ
- Tried enabling CodeQL in the Github UI, but it failed complaining about the Java version.

### Answered questions

- Regular Spring or Reactive?  Best to use regular Spring, for each of troubleshooting, testing.
- Gradle or Maven? Maven, since we have experience on our team
Demo application at [pulibrary/bento_search_spring_experiment](https://github.com/pulibrary/bento_search_spring_experiment)

figgy.title: PDFs should work in read-only mode

comments.body:
We recently made PDFs serve in the case of an optimistic lock error. We could just generalize that to rescue everything, or we could figure out what the error would be in read-only and add that specifically.

https://github.com/pulibrary/figgy/commit/500bda231dd02bbf1ba2fb7823a3731d4c58e18c

Migration has been run successfully on `figgy-staging2`. `figgy-web-staging-1` superficially appears to also be hooked up but should be considered to be in an unknown state until the full playbook runs successfully on it.

Next steps for production migration:

Get ansible playbook running on Figgy Production all the way through on all the boxes before we start
Add info about only doing half the web servers in prod

pdc_describe.title: Updating the ror pattern to remove the invalid character
The ROR pattern has an invalid character
Some notifications are being sent twice

comments.body:
@bess it's likely because you are in the list of moderators twice...  I would guess you added a role in the rails console?
![Screenshot 2023-08-24 at 9 04 34 AM](https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/assets/1599081/cd743de5-1a3f-4035-8f11-f1198f5274a6)

I went into the console, you had group_admin for all groups and also group_admin for each group individually.  You also had collection_admin, which should not even exist at this point...  I ran:
```
user = User.find_by(uid: 'bs3097')
user.remove_role :collection_admin
user.remove_role :group_admin
# The above drops all roles related to group admin, so I then added you back for both
user.add_role :group_admin, Group.plasma_laboratory
user.add_role :group_admin, Group.research_data
```
You are now in the list only once:
![Screenshot 2023-08-24 at 9 11 45 AM](https://github.com/pulibrary/pdc_describe/assets/1599081/9255d6c4-4c3b-47d7-a638-50403c17bcc7)

princeton_ansible.title: open up CIFS port for iiif-staging
[TIGERDATA] Fix port to be https port for mediaflux
Block deploying from Tower if a branch is failing CI in GitHub

comments.body: Currently [this line](https://github.com/pulibrary/princeton_ansible/blob/dd079eda1613729aab5eed750d4173e9fce54dc9/playbooks/deploy_code.yml#L19) sets `required_contexts` to `[]` - in other words, no contexts required. If we set this to a variable, we should be able to require passing CI by default in Tower while allowing an override. Need to find out what values do the thing we want.

Relevant [API documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/rest/deployments/deployments?apiVersion=2022-11-28#create-a-deployment).

Possibly relevant docs about [contexts in GitHub Actions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/contexts).

princeton_ansible.title: [Figgy] figgy does not use kakadu any more
first draft of CDH error handling

comments.body: Note that this will return that "Are you on the VPN?" page for all `403 Forbidden` errors for these sites. We may want to add more info if that is likely to happen for other reasons beyond "Nope, i was not on the VPN."

Thank you for working on it. General approach seems good to me.

My initial thought was to keep the PUL logo (as shown on other error pages - since this is running on PUL infrastructure) but also add a CDH logo, maybe underneath it - as a way of signalling to people whether or not they are in the right place (if they intended to access a CDH site).  Does that makes sense?

I'm not sure what links should be there - we don't have CDH specific support lists currently; my preference would be to use the existing lsupport mailing address if we can (as you have here).

A couple variants of the CDH logo are available here https://github.com/Princeton-CDH/cdh-web/tree/main/sitemedia/img/cdh-logo-assets 
There are more variants in a google drive folder, but I think the default one should work here.  Do you want to have a local copy because we don't want to introduce any possible errors while serving the error page?

My main question about the functionality is how can we test it and how do we make sure this doesn't override app-specific error pages.  We typically implement custom 404 and 500 pages; some apps may have an app-specific 403 that should not be handled (e.g. for REST API type requests). Can a 403 triggered by nginxplus IP restriction be differentiated from an app 403?

Could try this out on CDH staging sites first before rolling it out to the production sites?
